body: Could you provide `alacritty --print-events` while you're reproducing this issue and not `strace` mixed output, thanks.
Yes, of course.  How do I do that?  The command I'm running right now is `alacritty --print-events | tee output.txt`.
Just do `alacritty --print-events > out.txt` and post the txt file here, don't forget to repro your issue during it.

Seems like `Shift + Minus` doesn't work, however `Control + Minus` works. The problem is that we don't get a virtual key code from https://github.com/rust-windowing/winit , so bindings is failing. This issue is true for both X11 and Wayland AFAICS.  The `\u{1f}` is a correct value btw, so the problem is virtual key code. I'd recommend to bind by scancode on Linux for now(12 in your case).

```
- { key: 12,     mods: Control|Shift, chars "hi"           }
```

This is likely related to rust-windowing/winit#1443 , but I'm not sure, since we have Wayland here.

cc @chrisduerr .

Just to be sure, I tried again with an almost empty config.  The only thing in the file is.
```
key_bindings:
  - { key: Backslash,  mods: Control|Shift, chars: "\x00|"    }
  - { key: Minus,      mods: Control|Shift, chars: "hi"    }
```
and still had the same problem.  Also, I don't know if this helps at all, but pressing Ctrl+Shift+-
```
$ showkey -a

Press any keys - Ctrl-D will terminate this program

^_ 	 31 0037 0x1f
```
though I assume that's pretty normal.
As I said, `Control + Shift + Minus` doesn't have virtual key code, so the only option is to bind by scancode, as I said before. I can repro this bug on my system with both backends.
Yeah, this is identical to the X11 winit issue. The `DeviceEvent` contains a key but the `WindowEvent` does not.
Oh sorry, sorry. Didn't see that.  Thank you!!

issue.title: Vi mode: "Last" action seems to have no effect

rename.to: WindowEvent missing virtual keycode on Linux

issue.title: Alt+Shift+] keymapping not working in X11
issue.body:
I've stumbled on to an odd problem where the following mapping does not work
```
key_bindings:
  # Send space + [] to vim to change buffer
  - { key: LBracket, mods: Alt|Shift, chars: "\x20\x5b" }
  - { key: RBracket, mods: Alt|Shift, chars: "\x20\x5d" }
```
while instead using only alt, with
```
key_bindings:
  - { key: LBracket, mods: Alt, chars: "\x20\x5b" }
  - { key: RBracket, mods: Alt, chars: "\x20\x5d" }
```
seems to work.

Am I doing something wrong, or is X/xfce hijacking something, or is it a bug?

First i suspected that using Shift might invalidate the `L/RBracket` key designation, as Shift normally would *curly* brackets instead of square ones, but as I understand, `L/RBracket` catches both curly and square brackets, right?


*P.S. for the curious: as the comment suggests, I'm using the keymapping to send `"leader"+]` in vim, which in turn triggers `:bn` (next buffer) mapping there.*

### System

OS: Arch Linux
Version: alacritty 0.4.3
Linux/BSD: X11, xfce

### Logs
 `alacritty --print-events`:
```
[2020-06-09 17:16:22.277699094] [INFO] glutin event: NewEvents(WaitCancelled { start: Instant { tv_sec: 33147, tv_nsec: 233421123 }, requested_resume: None })
```

issue.title: SearchBackward key binding not working in 0.5.0-rc2 vi mode
issue.body:
In `alacritty.yml`, Shift-/ is documented as key to start a backwards search in Vi mode, but it seems to do nothing for me. The ForwardSearch key binding works for me. 

I tried explicitly adding the keybinding from the samle `alacritty.yml` to my own file, but that didn't help. 

I tested multiple times to see if it might be user error but I couldn't get it to work. 

### System

OS: Linux
Version:alacritty 0.5.0-rc2 (714bbb7)
Linux/BSD: X11

issue.title: Some key bindings ignored in Vi-mode
issue.body:
The vi-mode command  `Shift-4` to navigate to the end of the line doesn't seem to work on my system.

I use default key bindings, en-US layout

 `alacritty --print-events` output for `Shift-4` (I hope this is the relevant line): 
```
[2020-08-14 16:54:31.272178692] [INFO] glutin event: DeviceEvent { device_id: DeviceId(X(DeviceId(14))), event: Key(KeyboardInput { scancode: 5, state: Pressed, virtual_keycode: Some(Key4), modifiers: SHIFT }) }
[2020-08-14 16:54:31.272275899] [INFO] glutin event: WindowEvent { window_id: WindowId(X(WindowId(18874370))), event: KeyboardInput { device_id: DeviceId(X(DeviceId(3))), input: KeyboardInput { scancode: 5, state: Pressed, virtual_keycode: None, modifiers: SHIFT }, is_synthetic: false } }
```



### System

OS: Ubuntu 18.04.4
Version: alacritty 0.5.0
Linux/BSD: X11/i3

issue.title: Escape key bindings don't work with CapsLock remapped to Escape
issue.body:
I have CapsLock remapped to Escape on my system (both keys work as Escape). This is done via the following setting in the config of my window manager (Sway):

```
xkb_options caps:escape,altwin:ctrl_alt_win,ctrl:swap_lalt_lctl,ctrl:rctrl_ralt,grp:alts_toggle
```

This also swaps Ctrls and Alts which works fine in all applications including Alacritty. The issue is that Alacritty key bindings that involve the Escape key don't work when I use CapsLock. For example, I can't cancel selection and search. I tried to define a custom key binding which also doesn't work with CapsLock:

```
key_bindings:
    - { key: Escape, mods: Control, action: ToggleViMode }
```

All these key bindings work with the actual Escape key though.


### System

OS:  Void Linux
Version: 0.5.0
WM: Sway, Wayland

### Logs

With `print_events: true` I get the following relevant events when I press the CapsLock key:

```
[2020-10-30 20:57:01.399223032] [INFO] glutin event: WindowEvent { window_id: WindowId(Wayland(WindowId(94400373074288))), event: KeyboardInput { device_id: DeviceId(Wayland(DeviceId)), input: KeyboardInput { scancode: 58, state: Pressed, virtual_keycode: None, modifiers: (empty) }, is_synthetic: false } }
```

```
[2020-10-30 20:57:01.430422339] [INFO] glutin event: WindowEvent { window_id: WindowId(Wayland(WindowId(94400373074288))), event: KeyboardInput { device_id: DeviceId(Wayland(DeviceId)), input: KeyboardInput { scancode: 58, state: Released, virtual_keycode: None, modifiers: (empty) }, is_synthetic: false } }
```
